He insists that there is no other reason for DHS to suspend the trusted traveler and global entry programs other than politics. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('tablet', 'lb21', 'tablet-tw-ad-lb21', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: GOV. ANDREW CUOMO (D-NY)
utterances.sentences: It's all politics. And it's retaliation and it's reprisal because it really upset that we give licenses to undocumented people. That's why we have our license program. But, if they think they are going to extort New York into giving them the database of undocumented people, they're wrong. I will never do that. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb13', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb13', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: CORKE
utterances.sentences: Says he will never do that. But the White House remains defiant tonight calling this a matter of public safety and simply making sure that trusted travelers are, in fact, properly vetted.

utterances.speaker: STEPHANIE GRISHAM, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY
utterances.sentences: I think that it's unfortunate that they are calling - making this about politics. This is about the security of our country and the American people and nothing else. Information sharing is very, very important between states and the federal government specifically DHS and ICE.

utterances.speaker: CORKE
utterances.sentences: Stephanie Grisham speaking there then the Governor has said, Ed that he would be willing to amend this idea of access to some information and some material but he says if they can't figure out a way to make this all work, they might even sue. Ed, back to you.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Kevin Corke, thank you. Here now exclusively Chad Wolf, he is the Acting Secretary of Homeland Security. Mr. Secretary, thanks for coming in.

utterances.speaker: CHAD WOLF, ACTING HOMELAND SECURITY SECRETARY
utterances.sentences: Thank you, Ed. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb14', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb14', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: It is sure that Democratic Governor. He says you are guilty of extortion.

utterances.speaker: WOLF
utterances.sentences: Well, I think that's just totally inaccurate. This is about security and it's not about politics. I have been absolutely clear with the Governor and any other New York state individual or lawmaker that I talk with. CVP needs access to this data base to run their security checks on trusted travelers. It's that plain and simple. There is no politics about it. They cut off access. We need it back to totally vet these individuals.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: And in fact the Sheriff's Association here in New York State seems to be backing you I want to point out. They say to that the Governor our inability under the law to share this DMV data with federal immigration officers jeopardizes the safety of those police officers. We find it offensive that in order to avail our own deputies of this DMV data that they need for their own safe operations we were coerced into signing a nondisclosure agreement with jeopardizes the safety of our federal partners. We've seen police officers, as you know, law enforcement all around this country targeted. We see it all the time. Is this adding to that? How desperate is the situation?

utterances.speaker: WOLF
utterances.sentences: Yes, I believe it is. I think what we have seen over the last week or so is a number of law enforcement associations and officials in the state of New York come out against this law because of how who dangerous it is. Again, it restricts information sharing with DHS across the board. Again, that's not only for trusted traveler programs that we are talking about here it is also for customs enforcement it is also for national security and law enforcement purposes. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb15', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb15', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); } An individual coming into the country CVP officers need this information to determine is this a legitimate person coming in or do we need to take a closer look at that we are only able to do that if we share information. So after 9/11 this is what 9/11 was all about. One of the lessons learned was we needed to share information. We need to tear down these silos. We don't need to be building these up to keep information from law enforcement officials.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: We mentioned, pardon me that the President was tweeting about how he wants to get rid of these lawsuits, New York State coming after him in various ways. The Governor did an interview where he went further. And not just attacking the President but going after you. Listen.

utterances.speaker: CUOMO
utterances.sentences: You are knocking on the door saying I will burn down the house if you don't give me entry? I will give you entry for the TTP enrollees on the case-by-case basis. Don't burn down the house. They said I'm burning down the house anyway, all right? So now they're just arsonists.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: How do you respond to that? if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb16', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb16', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: WOLF
utterances.sentences: Well, I would say I'm not sure why you passed the law to begin with. So they passed law back July of 19 and it took effect in December. And so they clearly knew what they were doing. They clearly knew the impacts of this and I'm not sure that they really fully understood it. So we continue to work with. Look, we want to find a solution to this. The solution requires them to turn on access so that we can vet trusted travelers. I have been very clear about that. I will continue to be very clear about that. This is about law enforcement. This is about security. This is about the ability to connect those dots and to share that information. And, again, it's particularly interesting coming from New York again, from where 9/11 occurred. We want to make sure that we share information and not continue to withhold information.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Safety paramount, no doubt. You might also be interested in when you talk about New York officials coming after you, Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, the Congresswoman, is tweeting tonight: Trump is publicly admitting that he is holding global entry for New Yorkers hostage in exchange for dropping lawsuits against him and his families law-breaking behavior. Those are her words. This is corrupt, illegal and authoritarian. I hope Collins and Murkowski are proud of their votes. She is of course referring to the impeachment trial not guilty and rest. Susan Collins saying the President learned his lesson about quid pro quos. How do you respond to this one?

utterances.speaker: WOLF
utterances.sentences: This is their talking point. They keep bringing it back to talking politics. It has nothing to do with politics. It has to do with security. The President understands that I believe the Governor understands that which is why he is now allowing access or at least providing that option for us to vet trusted travelers. So, it's beyond politics. It's about security and whether DHS has the ability to do their job or not. And, again, we see a number of states. We have five other states that are withholding information from DHS. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb17', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb17', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); } So it's a very dangerous precedent that we're setting here and the department, again, needs this information and New York is the only state and I think that bears repeating the only state that prohibits information- sharing with both ICE and CVP officials trying to do their job. Law enforcement, customs, and vetting trusted travelers the only state.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Those officials have an important job keeping this country safe you do as well Mr. Secretary that's why we appreciate your time tonight. Thank you.

utterances.speaker: WOLF
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: In the meantime the Senate today voting to limit President Trump's authority to take military action against Iran. Republican Senator Kevin Cramer strongly opposed that measure and stood up for the President's power. He's on deck to explain why he thinks the Senate just inflicted major damage on our national security.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: We just took out the world's top terrorist Qassem Soleimani, ending his evil reign of terror forever. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb18', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb18', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: President Trump just this week touting the killing of Iranian terror leader Qassem Soleimani who was killed in a drone strike ordered by the commander-in-chief just last month. Today, though, the Senate passed a measure to prevent the president from taking similar action in the future passing a new war powers resolution by vote of 55 to 45. My next guest voted no on that measure. He is Republican Senator Kevin Cramer from North Dakota. He joins me live now. Senator, thanks for coming in.

utterances.speaker: SEN. KEVIN CRAMER (R-ND)
utterances.sentences: My pleasure. Thank you, Ed.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: What is your biggest fear about this measure? if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb19', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb19', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: CRAMER
utterances.sentences: Well, my biggest fear about it is I think it actually weakens the United States position and certainly weakens the president's hand as he deals with Iran and others, frankly, in the region. The other thing about it, while it's a good discussion to have as we talk about article one powers, separation of powers. What the Constitution says about who has the power to declare war, the president hasn't declared war. Soleimani was shot and killed while he was in Iraq. It was in response to recent events that took the life of Americans and tried to take the life of many more in our embassy.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CRAMER
utterances.sentences: So, it was justified. And I think this resolution frankly does more to embarrass the president than it does to make Americans safer. And, I think it could have the unintended consequence of demoralizing troops who, you know, who need to know that the president can have their back --

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Senator -- if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb20', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb20', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: CRAMER
utterances.sentences: -- and may wonder that.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: In fact, didn't Democrats after the president took out this terror leader, we heard Democrats suggesting it was a bad idea. It was going to backfire, blow up in our faces and spark a war with Tehran that never materialized?

utterances.speaker: CRAMER
utterances.sentences: In fact, just the opposite happened. And it deescalated. Remember, any escalation in the conflict between the United States and Iran has been at the hands of Iran. And, in fact, President Trump was quite patient with Iran when they took out, you know, took out our drone, you might recall. He didn't respond when at least didn't respond with any, you know, kinetic action. Same when they fired at other assets, whether it's ships in the straits or, you know --

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: He considered airstrikes, as you know and pulled back.

utterances.speaker: CRAMER
utterances.sentences: They did. They didn't pull back. That's exactly right, which I think was appropriate. But when they crossed that line of taking a human life, an American life and attacking our embassy, and, remember, too --

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Yes. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb21', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb21', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: CRAMER
utterances.sentences: -- that he was in Iraq. He was not in Iran. I think all of that is justified and I think some of the people who voted for the resolution believe it was justified. I heard Mike Lee say that in fact on Fox News earlier today.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: CRAMER
utterances.sentences: But what we're doing with this resolution, I mean, we are not at war with Iran. We're not -- I don't think we're likely to be at war with Iran.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CRAMER
utterances.sentences: It really restates what the Constitution already says and the Constitution is more than adequate to, you know, to that task.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: But, Senator --

utterances.speaker: CRAMER
utterances.sentences: Because what do we do every other country pass AUMF resolution on Canada --

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CRAMER
utterances.sentences: -- or, you know, North Korea? I mean, you know, we shouldn't preempt the Constitution.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: But if your position makes so much sense why didn't Mike Lee and several other Republicans join you?

utterances.speaker: CRAMER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Instead, Mike Lee, Rand Paul and others in a Republican led Senate as you know --

utterances.speaker: CRAMER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: -- challenged the president. Why?

utterances.speaker: CRAMER
utterances.sentences: So, I think, Ed, because there is a lot of pent up frustration with this -- with the general issue of war powers. The fact that we continue to take action based on 2001 and 2002 AUMFs, those are reasonable positions. They are reasonable frustrations. And we ought to have a reasonable discussion about them. I just don't like it in the context of this conflict that we have right now. Because there is so much at stake in the Middle East, including Iran.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Absolutely.

utterances.speaker: CRAMER
utterances.sentences: But particularly Iraq and the other countries. So, to me, it was just a matter of context.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Senator, I've got 30 seconds left.

utterances.speaker: CRAMER
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: The president going back to 2016 in the campaign promised to end the so-called endless wars. Mike Lee and others are now saying they want to see Afghanistan end. Can this president get there while still protecting and making sure -- America and making sure that it's not a terrorist safe haven?

utterances.speaker: CRAMER
utterances.sentences: Well, it depends on what end -- you know, what you think end means. We just had a hearing this week on Afghanistan in the armed services committee. I think it's clear that to keep it safe we are doing much less in Afghanistan, you know, with U.S. troops and much depending much more on Afghan troops. We need to continue that but we can't completely pull out and leave all the important work that's already been done --

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Absolutely.

utterances.speaker: CRAMER
utterances.sentences: -- go, you know, a little backwards. So.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Well, Senator, we still have thousands of troops as you note in harm's way.

utterances.speaker: CRAMER
utterances.sentences: Indeed.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: You are tackling a big subject tonight. We appreciate you coming in and talk about it.

utterances.speaker: CRAMER
utterances.sentences: My pleasure. Thank you for the opportunity, Ed.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: All right. Thank you, Senator. Still ahead, new comments from Attorney General William Barr defending his role in the Roger Stone case while urging the president to stop tweeting about it. Plus, new pleas from Democrats to get behind anybody but Bernie.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: The possibility of having a Democratic socialist at the top of the presidential ticket being met with push back tonight from some skittish Democrats who fear Bernie Sanders stands no chance of beating President Trump. Washington Post columnist Max Boot writing, please, Democrats, do the smart thing and coalesce quickly around one of the three moderates, Pete Buttigieg, Amy Klobuchar or Mike Bloomberg who is still standing after the first two contests. Joe Biden, he writes, is down for the count. The future of our democracy might depend on it. Here now Guy Benson, host of the Buy Benson show and a Fox News contributor. Good evening, Guy.

utterances.speaker: GUY BENSON, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.sentences: Hey, Ed.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: This freak out that's playing out is fascinating to watch in part because when they talk about, hey, get a moderate to save us like Amy Klobuchar. If you look at her Senate voting record it's actually quite liberal. But just compared to Bernie Sanders, it's not that liberal. And in the case of Pete Buttigieg he says he'd be the most progressive president ever yet they are trying to call him a moderate.

utterances.speaker: BENSON
utterances.sentences: It's all relative. I guess relative to Bernie Sanders a socialist, many people are moderates. I think most of these people are in fact quite liberal. You are definitely right about that, Ed. But this whole freak out is fascinating for more than one reason to believe. One of them is it's giving me PTSD and these flashbacks to four years ago, where I remember lots of things that I wrote and tweeted and said about consolidation and if we don't consolidate someone is going to get the nomination. Because I was very much a critic of candidate Donald Trump. And there were all these different machinations and ideas that people had. And ultimately, it didn't work when people would drop out of the race. A lot of folk's second choice was actually Donald Trump. So, I think sometimes elites getting all concerned and telling people what has to happen and when, it doesn't work out quite that well.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Well, it's interesting you say that because in the end obviously Donald Trump not only got the nomination for the Republicans but won the presidency.

utterances.speaker: BENSON
utterances.sentences: Correct.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: And so, when Speaker Pelosi as the Democratic leader was pressed about all of this today, she said what, me, worry? Watch.

utterances.speaker: REP. NANCY PELOSI (D-CA)
utterances.sentences: We are calm, cool and collected. This is not -- I mean, just because some people may be speaking out about not liking one candidate or another. That's the Democratic way. It's politics. It's a messy business.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Is she right? That this might play out well for the Democrats or is she maybe little more nervous than she is letting on.

utterances.speaker: BENSON
utterances.sentences: Calm, cool, and collected so much so that she is ripping up pages of the State of the Union address. That's Nancy. Look, I think that if she had her way, she would absolutely want to help nudge voters away from Bernie Sanders. You hear the freak out from not just columnists like Matt Boot -- Max Boot who used to be a conservative and now is a liberal. He used to tell conservatives how to think. Now he is trying to tell liberals how to think and vote which I think is --

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Because he doesn't like the president.

utterances.speaker: BENSON
utterances.sentences: Right. But I think Pelosi is looking at this situation and saying maybe it's not useful for me to weigh in on this. Let people decide what they're going to do. Don't put my thumb on the scale but some of her members, some of those moderate members who are majority makers, they are blabbing to reporters all over this town --

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BENSON
utterances.sentences: -- saying we cannot have Bernie at the top of the ticket or I am totally cooked. She definitely knows that but she recognizes, I think, that the establishment going too hard against a guy like Bernie could actually strengthen him and again, that's the Trump effect.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Give him more fuel, perhaps. Finally, speaking of freak outs. Interesting what's happening in Nevada where you have the caucuses coming up. It's the next big contest for Democrats and the culinary union is so powerful. Restaurant workers, casino workers, the rest. And interesting that you might think they would be for Bernie Sanders and who keeps talking about working people. But they came out today in Las Vegas and said we're not going to endorse anyone because, in part, some of their members are freaking out that Bernie Sanders with Medicare for all government run healthcare might take away their generous Cadillac healthcare plan that they've gotten private health insurance. So here you have people on the left saying, hey, let's have government, you know, Medicare for all. It will be great for you. And union workers are saying wait a second. That's not better than I have now.

utterances.speaker: BENSON
utterances.sentences: Not might, would. Medicare for all, single payer healthcare would eliminate the healthcare plans of these union workers. So, there are two really interesting things happening with this non- endorsement from the culinary union. Number one, they are, I think, driving home and underscoring the massive political risk of single payer healthcare, Medicare for all. One hundred eighty million people would be uprooted from the healthcare that they have. Most people are satisfied with the healthcare that they have including these union workers. Bernie Sanders and AOC and Liz Warren and that whole crowd say no, the wand is waived. The government takes over.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BENSON
utterances.sentences: That's all gone. The other thing is Bernie bros, some of his hard- core supporters were so angry --

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BENSON
utterances.sentences: -- about them these facts about healthcare they swarmed them with threats and all sorts of intimidation. And that really ticked off the union guys. Good work, Bernie bros.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: It may backfire not just there in Nevada but in other places where he needs union support where it's going to be interesting to watch it. Guy Benson, we appreciate you coming.

utterances.speaker: BENSON
utterances.sentences: You bet.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: In the meantime, Attorney General William Barr comes out blazing against some of those attacks like this.

utterances.speaker: PELOSI
utterances.sentences: The attorney general has stoop to such levels. He's lied to Congress, which he will be in contempt. He has engaged in these activities. What a sad disappointment to our country.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Well, Republican Congressman Mark Meadows you see him there. He's got something to say about that. But so does Democrat Eric Swalwell. He is leaving the door open to another impeachment probe. That is next.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Attorney General William Barr tonight defending his handling of the Roger Stone case, maintaining his department's recommendation of a lesser sense for Roger Stone came without any consultation at all from the White House but adding that President Trump should stay out of it and stop tweeting about it.

utterances.speaker: BARR
utterances.sentences: The president has never asked me to do anything in a criminal case. However, to have public statements and tweets made about the department, about our people in the department, our men and women here, about cases pending in the department, and about judges before whom we have cases make it impossible for me to do my job. I have not discussed the Roger Stone case at the White House. The fact that the tweets are out there and correspond to things we are doing at the department sort of give grist to the mill and that's why I think it's time to stop the tweeting about Department of Justice criminal cases.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Here now Republican Congressman Mark Meadows a member of the House oversight committee, a key ally of the president. Congressman, thanks for coming in.

utterances.speaker: REP. MARK MEADOWS (R-NC)
utterances.sentences: Great to be with you, Ed, thanks.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: The attorney general seems to be saying directly to the president stay out of this.

utterances.speaker: MEADOWS
utterances.sentences: Well, you know, it's real easy for the attorney general to opine on the president's social media tactics but the very fact that we are talking about Roger Stone and the fact that the original sentencing guidelines from the DOJ were inappropriate was highlighted by the President of the United States. That being said, General Barr is doing a good job of trying to restore the confidence in the Department of Justice and FBI after a debacle in the whole Mueller investigation. And so, I know that he will call the balls and strikes as he already has. But ultimately, the president is right to call out this injustice.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Sure. I see that you believe it's an injustice. But you are looking backward to what happened at the FBI and the Justice Department before. What about looking forward? The attorney general seems to be sending a message to the president who nominated him. I can't do my job if you are going to interfere.

utterances.speaker: MEADOWS
utterances.sentences: Well, listen, he is not interfering. What he did was make a comment about what he saw was wrong. And so, there is no interference. In fact, in that particular lead in that General Barr was saying that they have not discussed this and that that was not part of it. And so, he is not actually interfering in that. But the other important thing is we do have to look backwards. We have to look at the context of the last three years of a truly partisan investigation that was based on conspiracies that were not actually there and, yet, you hear Eric Swalwell talking about he wants to do another impeachment based on this? Listen, they have a difficult enough time getting an app to count votes in Iowa, let alone trying to weigh in on this.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: We will give the congressman, Eric Swalwell, who is here standing by a chance to respond to that in a moment. In the meantime, here is Speaker Pelosi demanding a new investigation. Watch.

utterances.speaker: PELOSI
utterances.sentences: We also saw the president this week demonstrate once again that he has no respect for the rule of law. This is the abuse of power that the president is again trying to manipulate federal law enforcement to serve his political interest. A.G. Barr has deeply damaged the rule of law by withdrawing the DOJ's sentencing recommendation. This all must be investigated.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: How do you respond to the speaker?

utterances.speaker: MEADOWS
utterances.sentences: Listen, the speaker loves to criticize General Barr, loves to double down on her criticism of President Trump. But she has been consistent in both of those things. Here is the interesting thing is, as she looks at it and we are talking about the rule of law. What about the FISA abuse and the hearings that should come out of that? What about what we've had with Inspector General Horowitz? There is not a single hearing on Capitol Hill. They turn a blind eye and a deaf ear to all of that. So, if we want to get to the bottom of it and help --

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MEADOWS
utterances.sentences: -- A.G. Barr actually restore confidence, let's actually do that and start getting to the bottom of what went wrong with all the FISA abuse.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Well, to your point, John Durham, as you know the U.S. attorney from Connecticut is taking a look at all of that. We'll see what he does or does not do in the months ahead. In the meantime, last question. It's not just Speaker Pelosi pressuring the president. John Kelly, as you know, his former chief of staff gave a speech where he talked about Colonel Vindman, among other things, he said, he did exactly what we teach them to do from cradle to grave. He went and told his boss what he just heard. He is talking about Ukraine. His -- the president's former chief of staff is suggesting that some of these firings are sending a chilling message. How do you respond?

utterances.speaker: MEADOWS
utterances.sentences: Well, General Kelly is wrong about that. I happen to be in seven hours of deposition with Lieutenant Colonel Vindman. He didn't go to his boss. He didn't go to the chain of command. He picked up the phone and called someone else outside of the NSC. So, with all due respect to General Kelly he is just wrong on Lieutenant Colonel Vindman. The president was right to have him escorted out. There needs -- others that need to be escorted out as well.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Congressman Mark Meadows, we appreciate you coming in.

utterances.speaker: MEADOWS
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Here now as we mentioned in fairness, Democratic Congressman Eric Swalwell. He is a member of the House judiciary and intelligence committee. He joins me here in New York. Congressman, thanks for coming in.

utterances.speaker: REP. ERIC SWALWELL (D-CA)
utterances.sentences: Yes. The bus is going to need a wheel alignment. Everyone keeps getting thrown under it. You know, all these heroes of the Trump administration. John Kelly, Bill Barr, now they are the villains. I think that's just a theme we see.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Your name was invoked --

utterances.speaker: SWALWELL
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: -- by Congressman Meadows, so you get a chance to respond.

utterances.speaker: SWALWELL
utterances.sentences: Yes. What I have said all along is that, just because the president was acquitted doesn't mean we're not going to use the tools we have to hold him accountable. We learned in the impeachment inquiry when we launched the investigation, Ukraine got the aid. Now we did it to hold him accountable. We wanted future presidents to know that the standard was not lowered. But we also learned when you check the president, the right thing ends up happening. So, we're not taking any of our options off the table. None of us wake up to work on impeachment. And if the president is listening, we want to work with you on prescription drugs, background checks, and infrastructure. And I would strike a deal on any of those.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: But we're going to get to that question of impeachment and other issues of the day.

utterances.speaker: SWALWELL
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Here is the president today with our own Geraldo Rivera talking about the Roger Stone case. He said what they did to Roger Stone was a disgrace. We actually have the sound. Let's do it.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: What did they did to Roger Stone was a disgrace in terms of everything. Right from the beginning. Twenty-nine FBI agents loaded up with the most powerful rifles and machine guns.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Congressman, it's been pointed out people sometimes get convicted for rape in this country and get four or five years in prison. He is going to get nine years in prison? How is that fair?

utterances.speaker: SWALWELL
utterances.sentences: Well, he lied to Congress and he kept updating his story by sending multiple letters up to us.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: But is lying to Congress worse than raping somebody?

utterances.speaker: SWALWELL
utterances.sentences: No. I prosecuted rapist and they should go away for the rest of their lives, as far as I'm concerned.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: So how is that fair is my question.

utterances.speaker: SWALWELL
utterances.sentences: I'm not going to compare his case to a rapist case.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: But let's compare.

utterances.speaker: SWALWELL
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: We should compare apples to apples. If you get four or five years for raping someone --

utterances.speaker: SWALWELL
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: -- how is it that lying to Congress -- which you should not do --

utterances.speaker: SWALWELL
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: -- to be clear. How can you get nine years for that and four or five years for raping someone?

utterances.speaker: SWALWELL
utterances.sentences: Anyone who gets four to five years for raping someone that's wrong. I don't support that. I'd speak out against this. Roger Stone lied to Congress to protect the president. And he actually falls within the guidelines. And the reason I think that the prosecutors are arguing, you know for the sentence is, one, we reward people who accept responsibility early in the proceeding. But if you go to trial, and remember, he didn't just go to trial. He was posting, you know, threats towards the judge during the trial and he had to be admonished for that. I think this should fall under the judge's discretion, and prosecutors, they should be able to make the recommendation without the president interfering.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: But the judge can overrule the president, can overrule the attorney general, right --

utterances.speaker: SWALWELL
utterances.sentences: That's right.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: -- and still do nine years or even, I'm told by Andy McCarthy and other legal analysts, even more than nine years. So, what's all the controversy about if the judge can overrule everyone anyway?

utterances.speaker: SWALWELL
utterances.sentences: Well, the president can still pardon him. Right? And also --

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Down the road. That's a big if.

utterances.speaker: SWALWELL
utterances.sentences: Show me the time that Bill Barr, you know, overruled a prosecutor and say, hey, this young black kid who is going to get disproportionately high sentence for, you know, crack cocaine. That's not right.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: But that's a --

utterances.speaker: SWALWELL
utterances.sentences: He is just doing that for the president.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: But pardon me, the judge, though.

utterances.speaker: SWALWELL
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: The federal judge here, regardless of what you attack with William Barr, the judge can say I still say nine years. Correct?

utterances.speaker: SWALWELL
utterances.sentences: That's right. Yes.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: OK. So, finally, impeachment. If you are upset about this and you don't think the president should intervene in the Roger Stone case, how could it rise to the level of an impeachable offense? Didn't we just go through that?

utterances.speaker: SWALWELL
utterances.sentences: I'm saying we are going to investigate this. That's what we're doing on the judiciary committee. Again, we check him. We stop his corruption. That's what we've learned. But what we also are seeing here is the president could just pardon Roger Stone, that would be wrong. But the fact that he is not doing that, and instead he is trying to show us the power he has that he can --

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: SWALWELL
utterances.sentences: -- infect the department of justice with his corruption --

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: But you are raising the suspect of a pardon over and over when we don't know if he is going to pardon him or not. We heard that as well about Manafort again and again. Democrats said he is going to pardon Manafort. He never did.

utterances.speaker: SWALWELL
utterances.sentences: I think this is -- this is worse that he is actually trying to have the Department of Justice do his dirty work because now you have infected a, you know, a department that is supposed to be independent with the president's corruption.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: When you said a moment ago and you just said it again. Corruption by the president. When, in fact, the judge can still send Roger Stone to jail for nine years. How is it corruption?

utterances.speaker: SWALWELL
utterances.sentences: Because the prosecutor's recommendation has great weight with the judges. And the prosecutor, and if you can help a friend, you also have prosecutors who can hurt your enemy. And the fact that the president would do either is what should be concerning for all.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: We're going to see how it plays out. Congressman, we appreciate you coming in, sir.

utterances.speaker: SWALWELL
utterances.sentences: Thanks, Ed.

utterances.speaker: HENRY
utterances.sentences: Thank you. That is The Story for Thursday, February 13th, 2020. But, as always, The Story continues. I will see you again tomorrow morning on America's Newsroom at 9 a.m. We will also be back here. I'll be filling in for Martha tomorrow night at 7 p.m. We'll see you tomorrow night on The Story.
